Earlier today, the Teamsters and the SEIU, the Service Employees International Union, announced plans to disaffiliate with the AF of L-CIO.
This is a major rift for the group, whose annual meeting in Chicago this week also marked the 50th anniversary of the labor merger which created it.
The two unions walk out with 1.8 million members, and there are several other major groups that may be poised to leave as well.
For more we turn now to Thomas Edsall of The Washington Post, who's in Chicago right now to cover the convention.
Good to have you on the program.
Good to be with you.
I imagine the mood there must be pretty tense about right now.
There's a mood of warfare here, I would say.

The forces supporting John Sweeney, the president of the AFL-CIO, and Sweeney himself have been very critical of the dissident unions and the dissident unions actually are fairly boisterous at this point, and are acting as if they're going to be pretty tough.
Mr.

Sweeney said even before the official departure was announced, `At a time when our corporate and conservative adversaries have created the most powerful anti-worker political machine in the history of our country, a divided movement hurts the hopes of working families for a better life.
He described the departure of these two unions as a grievous insult to working families.
All right.
Strong rhetoric.
Is there anything they can do about it?
There's really nothing he can do about it.

They both this morning gave him letters of disaffiliation with the AFL-CIO, and together they represent $20 million a year in dues, roughly 20 percent of the AFL's total budget, which is already in trouble.
There are two real schools on what's going to happen to organized labor now.
One argues that with competition and with a real fight going on it may actually result in more vitality and energy.
The other school is that a divided labor movement will just further weaken and collapse, and the erosion will continue.
Well, there are other members of the AF of L-CIO who may follow the Teamsters and the SEIU out.
There are at least two, and perhaps even a total of four.

The United Food and Commercial Workers and the hotel and needle trades workers in a union called UNITE HERE are both really on the verge of withdrawing, and they would represent another million and a half workers or more, really about 1.8 million.
And on top of that the Laborers' Union and the farm workers are sort of on the cusp and could well join them.
Mr.
Sweeney rose to prominence as the head of the SEIU himself.
Mr. Andy Stern, who's now the head of the SEIU, was his protege.
At what point, to what degree, if any, is this a clash of personality?
Well, I'm not sure about a--well, it is a clash of strategy and approach.
Stern took over the SEIU from Sweeney, and Sweeney many ways was Stern's mentor.
But Stern is a much more aggressive--he's a guy who will break icons.
He's not someone who believes in tradition.
He comes up from the civil rights movement.
He's the kind of guy who will break some glass on the way up the ladder.
Sweeney, in contrast, is a guy who believes in consensus, believes that the AFL is a federation that requires consensus.
He is a much more cautious leader, and Stern really is very actively opposed to the style of leadership that Sweeney has run this organization with.
There have been several high-profile Democratic Party politicians who were addressing the convention.
How are they addressing this issue?
Very cautiously.
In fact, they've been avoiding the press.
They told the staff here that they're in such hurry to get back to Washington that they have no time to meet with the press.
They make elliptical references indicating that they hope this breach is resolved.
I have to tell you I think none of them really want to get in between two friends who are fighting.
I mean, they have close allies on both sides, and it's not the kind of thing any politician likes to get near.
Well, among the things that--and we're talking mostly about Andy Stern, the president of the SEIU--James B.
Hoffa, no shrinking violet, either, is also involved in this.
Yes, they're both two outspoken guys--very different people, but both very outspoken, and both very critical of Sweeney.
One of the issues that Andy Stern has been very critical about and said that he may address in the future is the lack of political activism from the AF of L-CIO.
He's even proposed the idea of backing separate candidates in Democratic primaries.
He has proposed--one, he says that he's also willing to support Republicans, and he, in fact, was the single largest supporter of the Republican Governors' Association.
The SEIU gave it over half a million dollars in the last election cycle.
He also thinks that the part that unions ought to be backing, the primary challengers, two Democrats, in cases where the Democrat does not support the union position.
It's a much tougher stand than the Sweeney administration has taken.
And he's also--one of the fundamental complaints that you hear from the breakaway side is that not enough money is--there's too much money spent on politics and not enough on organization.
Is that a valid complaint?
It's not just that.

It's really also a much broader argument that Stern and his allies make, which is that the AFL-CIO should force its own members to start merging so that you'll have very big unions able to take on the very big international corporations and chains that we have now like Wal-Mart or Federal Express.

Stern's argument is that with 56 different unions from large to small, all competing amongst each other, they just cannot deal with companies that are international or cover the entire country, and it takes a whole different organizing strategy.
And he does want a lot more money put into organizing, yes.
And what's the next step for the breakaway side?
What did they say to me?
You sound - Alan, you sound as if your voice is coming out of the back end of a drainpipe, was one review from my voice teacher.
And so if I come into your bike store, and I want to buy a bike, how do you fit me for one?
They have formed a coalition called the Change to Win Coalition.
Hoffa says he's going to put $5 million a year into it; I imagine Stern is going to put in at least that much.
There are other unions that--the others that--UNITE HERE and Food and Commercial and Laborers and farm workers are all members.
That is going to be a coalition trying to do a lot more organizing.
Especially I think they may well target Wal-Mart, which is the big symbolic employer that all organized labor sees as their major adversary.
And finally, I guess the rift is now official.
But is there any hope for mending fences here?
I don't think there's any hope in the short term.
By that I mean probably at least six months and probably a few years.
I think Stern really wants to go on his own way.
Hoffa wants to go on his own way.
Hoffa also has a lot of bitterness against a lot of the members of the AFL-CIO, who he felt opposed him when he ran for the presidency.
So there are some big wounds here that are not going to be easily solved and dealt with in a short-term manner.
